mcqs.question: What happens if you do not use a CSS reset or normalization?
options: All browsers will render your page identically
Different browsers may render default styles differently
mcqs.explanation: Browsers have different default styles, so without a reset or normalization, pages can look inconsistent.

mcqs.question: Which of the following is a common CSS reset technique?
mcqs.explanation: This reset removes default margin and padding and applies `border-box` for easier box sizing.

mcqs.question: What is the main goal of using Normalize.css?
options: To remove all browser default styles
To make elements render more consistently across browsers
mcqs.explanation: Normalize.css preserves useful defaults but aims for consistent rendering across browsers.

mcqs.question: Where should you place your reset or normalization rules in your stylesheet?
options: At the top, before your custom styles
At the bottom, after all styles
mcqs.explanation: Place resets/normalizations at the top so your custom styles can override them.

mcqs.question: Which of these is NOT a benefit of using a CSS reset?
mcqs.explanation: A CSS reset does not affect animation support.

mcqs.question: What is a potential drawback of an aggressive CSS reset?
options: It might remove useful browser defaults
It makes your CSS less maintainable
It is not supported in Chrome
mcqs.explanation: Aggressive resets can remove helpful defaults, requiring you to redefine them.

mcqs.question: Which of these is a valid use of the universal selector in a reset?
mcqs.explanation: All of these are common universal selector reset techniques.

mcqs.question: Which of the following is true about Normalize.css?
options: It preserves some useful browser defaults
It only works on mobile browsers
mcqs.explanation: Normalize.css keeps useful defaults and normalizes the rest.

mcqs.question: What is the effect of `html { box-sizing: border-box; } * { box-sizing: inherit; }`?
options: All elements use the border-box sizing model
It adds a border to all elements
mcqs.explanation: This makes all elements use border-box, which is easier for sizing.

mcqs.question: Why is it recommended to customize resets for your project?
options: To avoid removing useful defaults you want to keep
mcqs.explanation: Customizing resets lets you keep useful defaults and avoid extra work.

mcqs.question: Which of these is a feature of Sanitize.css?
mcqs.explanation: Sanitize.css normalizes and enhances browser styles.

mcqs.question: What happens if you use both a reset and Normalize.css?
options: You get the benefits of both
There may be conflicts or redundant styles
It is required for all projects
mcqs.explanation: Using both can cause conflicts or unnecessary duplication.

mcqs.question: Which of these is NOT a side effect of using a CSS reset?
options: All elements have zero margin/padding by default
mcqs.explanation: Resets do not provide dark mode support.

mcqs.question: What is a best practice for using resets or normalizations?
options: Put them at the top, then override as needed
mcqs.explanation: Put resets at the top and override as needed for your design.

mcqs.question: Which is TRUE about browser default styles?
options: They are set by CSS frameworks
mcqs.explanation: Browser default styles are different, which is why resets/normalization are used.
